awd_titl_txt: E2CDA: Type II: Collaborative Research: Nanophotonic Lithium Niobate platform for next generation energy efficient and ultrahigh bandwidth optical interconnect
awd_abstract_narration:
High performance computing systems and data centers dissipate a large amount of power, much of which is spent on data transmission. Optical technology is well poised to increase the efficiency of data transfer, however it brings along new types of energy losses associated with devices responsible for converting the information from the electrical domain, used for computation, to the optical domain, used for communication. This program will overcome this hurdle and will enable realization of efficient and compact electrical-to-optical converters. The program addresses topics related to optical communications, material science, computer modeling, nanotechnology, and electronics, and therefore represents a unique training ground for students at all levels. To engage a wider audience, the team members will prepare public lectures focused on discussing the science and technology used to realize the communication systems that modern society heavily relies on. 

The goal of this project is development of highly integrated, micrometer scale, lithium-niobate electro-optic modulators, that have the potential to enable large communication rates with minimal energy consumption. This will allow for efficient data transfer that could meet demanding requirements of future high performance computing systems. The proposed program will advance the state of the art of optoelectronic devices, will explore new device concepts and system architectures, will develop nanofabrication techniques suitable for realization of integrated modulators, and will develop new communication methods.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we developed technologies that enable scaling up optical interconnects between computer servers inside data centers. A data center is a warehouse-sized building that houses thousands to tens of thousands of servers. Each server is similar to a high-performance desktop computer, but when thousands of servers are interconnected, they can work together on very large computing tasks, such as answering search queries, recognizing speech or images. The ever-more-complex computing tasks performed by data centers are increasingly referred to as ?machine learning? or ?artificial intelligence?, as they resemble or rival complicated tasks that, heretofore, could only be performed by humans.

In order to perform complex computing tasks, it is necessary to interconnect more and more computers, with faster interconnects. The interconnects are realized by optical fibers that carry signals modulated onto different colors of light. Each fiber can now carry as much as hundreds of billions of bits per second. But the connectivity requirements just keep expanding, and interconnects carrying several trillions of bits per second will be needed in just a few years. Scaling up the interconnects requires using more colors of light and modulating each one with data at a higher speed. This scaling up must be done while improving the efficiency of the interconnects, because data centers are now using a sizable fraction of the electrical power generating capacity in the US and other advanced countries.

A key device we developed is an optical comb generator that is fabricated using a material called thin-film lithium niobate. The comb generator is a light source that generates many different colors of light ? their spectrum comprises numerous lines resembling the teeth of comb ? which are very precisely spaced, facilitating their use in data interconnects. A comb generator and the optical interconnects using them may ultimately scale up to higher data rates while consuming less power than interconnects that rely upon separate lasers for generating each color of light.

In addition to demonstrating the optical comb generator concept, we developed designs for optical transmitters and optical receivers that work along with the comb generator to enable scaling up the interconnect data rates while minimizing their power consumption. These transmitters and receivers are called ?coherent? because they exploit the coherent properties of light ? the fact that light is made of waves that have well-defined phase ? in order to allow more wavelengths of light, each modulated by data at higher rates, to be conveyed by an optical fiber link.
